problem: Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$?
solution:
One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align*}
(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
\end{align*} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align*}
& (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\
\equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11}
\end{align*}
socratic_questions:
1. Can you explain what the given expression represent in modular arithmetic?
2. What does it mean to find an inverse modulo 11?
3. Can you describe the process of finding the inverse of a number modulo 11?
4. How can we express the expression $3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1}$ in terms of modulo 11?
5. Can you simplify the expression $(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}$ using the explicit method?
6. Is there an alternative way to simplify the expression using manipulation? If so, can you describe that method?
7. How can we determine the remainder when $a$ is divided by 11?
8. Can you explain why the remainder is 10 using the explicit method?
9. Can you explain why the remainder is still 10 using the alternative method?
